item.title: Expansion potential
item.description:
Source: TW

Śaṅkaradeva

Śaṅkaradeva’s Ekaśaraṇa Dharma (Assamese Vaiṣṇavism) lacked the strict caste framework, purity-pollution rules, etc. of Brahmanical Hinduism, yet it nevertheless lacked the capacity to compete with Christianity.

The sattrādhipatis were only successful at converting two groups to Vaiṣṇavism (i.e. Noctes and Wanchos of Tirap) with only a few exceptions (some Phoms, some eastern Rengma).

These two groups were unusually docile, paid nominal tribute to the Ahoms, and were vital suppliers of salt to the Ahoms along key trading routes like the Hukanjuri-Khonsa-Borduria route. Moreover, several Noctes had already adopted Theravāda Buddhism (via the Khamtis and Singphos) or Śāktism (via the Tai-Ahoms), unlike the tribes of the dangerous frontier zones.

item.title: Fluidity
item.description:
Source: TW

the whole issue of “no hindu identity” always seemed kinda silly to me, obviously when no such thing as christianity or islam exist, your divisions are going to be vaishnava vs shaiva. when larger, more strange, more alien groups come in the picture, your group identity expands. When people try to seek fixed identities etched in stone through the centuries, its irritating. i dont know why people cannot understand group identity is fluid, and not static.

item.title: Hindu groupings
item.description:
Source: TW

Mahābhārata grouping of valid paths: Veda, Sāṅkhya, Yoga, Pāśupata & Pāñcarātra

Niśvāsamukha (an early Śaiva tantra text) grouping:

  • Laukika: Vratas, Dānas, Tīrthayātras
  • Vaidika: Śrautasmārtādi
  • Ādhyātmika: Sāṅkhyā, Yoga
  • Atimārga: Pāśupata, Lākuliśa
  • Mantramārga: Siddhānta +++

These groupings, excluding Nāstika paths, are signs of a Hindu identity. Shows who were the members of the “Tānūnaptra” covenant at different points in time.
